abstract.text: Access to information may represent an important barrier to learning about and ultimately transferring to 4-year colleges for low-income community college students.
This article explores the role that access to information technology, in particular, plays in enhancing, or possibly detracting from, the transfer function of the community college.

Using data from the first-ever field experiment randomly providing free computers to students, we examine the relationships between access to home computers and enrollment in transferable courses and actual transfers to 4-year colleges.

The results from the field experiment indicate that the treatment group of students receiving free computers has a 4.5 percentage point higher probability of taking transferable courses than the control group of students not receiving free computers.

The evidence is less clear for the effects on actual transfers to 4-year colleges and the probability of using a computer to search for college information (which possibly represents one of the mechanisms for positive effects).
In both cases, point estimates are positive, but the confidence intervals are wide.

Finally, power calculations indicate that sample sizes would have to be considerably larger to find statistically significant treatment effects and reasonably precise confidence intervals given the actual transfer rate point estimates.

body_text.text: and interest in taking more demanding transferable courses (Jones 2002;Lenhart 2009; U.S. Department of Commerce 2004).
7 Because of these potentially opposing forces, the net effect of having access to a home computer on transferring among community college students is theoretically ambiguous.
An empirical test of the hypothesis is therefore needed, but has not been conducted in the previous literature.
This is due, in part, to the inherent selection problems in estimating the effects of personal computers on educational outcomes.

To address the lack of empirical evidence on the question and concerns about causal inference, we use data from the first-ever field experiment providing free computers to community college students for home use to explore the relationship between access to computers and transferring to 4-year colleges.
Participating students were randomly selected to receive free computers and their course-taking and transfer behavior was tracked in subsequent years.
The random-assignment evaluation is conducted with 286 entering students receiving financial aid at a large
7. The impact of the extensive use of Facebook among college students on academic outcomes has recently received some attention (Karpinski 2009 andPasek andHargittai 2009).
The attention is partly due to the dramatic increase in the use of social networking sites such as Facebook in the past few years (Lenhart 2009).
These concerns are similar to those over television (Zavodny 2006).
community college in Northern California.

Previous findings from the experiment provide some evidence that the randomly selected group of students receiving free computers achieved better educational outcomes than the control group that did not receive free computers, but the study does not examine the potential transfer function of the community college (Fairlie and London 2012).
8 In this article, we conduct a detailed analysis of the causal effects of home computers on the transfer function of community colleges for low-income students.
In an examination of the effects of home computers on several different educational outcomes, Fairlie and London (2012) find positive estimates of the effects on taking transfer courses.
We expand on that finding in several ways.
First, and foremost, we obtain new data from the National Student Clearinghouse on actual transfers to 4-year colleges among all participants in the experiment.
9 These data allow for an analysis of not only

8. Previous results from the experiment also indicate that estimates of the effects of home computers on graduating from community college are much smaller than nonexperimental estimates from matched CPS data suggesting that nonexperimental estimates may be biased upward (Fairlie and London 2012).
9. The Institutional Research Department at the community college recently analyzed transfer rates of all of its students through specially commissioned data from the National Student Clearinghouse.
We obtained these data for our sample of 286 students participating in the study providing a 4-year window in which to observe transfers.
whether computers affect interest or intent to transfer to a 4-year college but also whether they affect actual transfers.
These data as well as data on transfer course enrollment are taken from administrative data removing concerns about differential attrition or reporting biases.
Second, we report new estimates on treatment heterogeneity by educational goals.
Focusing on the effects of computers on transfers to 4-year colleges suggests that students with the initial goal of transferring versus those with another goal might be affected differently.
Third, new results on the effects of home computers on self-reported college search are reported.
These results provide suggestive evidence on possible mechanisms.

The findings on the effects on taking transfer courses, searching for college information, heterogeneity by educational goal, and actual transfer rates are also discussed in the context of the literature examining what contributes to transfer rates among community college students.
II.
THE FIELD EXPERIMENT
To examine the effects of home computers on transferring to 4-year colleges, we randomly assigned free computers to entering community college students who were receiving financial aid.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: The students attended Butte College, which is located in Northern California and has a total enrollment of over 20,000 students.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: Compared with the average community college in the United States, Butte College is larger, but does not differ substantially in the composition of its student body.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: For example, Butte College has a roughly similar share of female students as the U.S. total (55.0% compared with 58.5%) and roughly similar share of nonminority students (65.4% compared with 60.8%).
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: To implement the field experiment, letters advertising the computer giveaway program were sent to all financial aid students with less than 24 units attending the college in fall 2006 (see Fairlie and London 2012 for more details on the field experiment).
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: In fall 2006, there were 1,042 financial aid students and 6,681 students in total who met the course unit restriction.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: Participating students were required to return a baseline questionnaire and consent form releasing future academic records from the college for the study.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: Students who already owned computers were not excluded from participating in the lottery because their computers may have been much older and not fully functional with the latest software and hardware.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: 10 There were 286 students who participated in the study with 141 of these students receiving free computers.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: All the computers were refurbished and were provided by Computers for Classrooms, Inc., a computer refurbisher located in Chico, California.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: 11 Internet service was not provided as part of the experiment, but we found at the end of the study that more than 90% of the treatment group had Internet service.
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: Because of high rates of Internet subscription among computer owners we cannot identify separate effects of computers and the Internet, which has been a problem in previous studies (Fairlie, Beltan, and Das 2010).
body_text.section: II. THE FIELD EXPERIMENT

body_text.text: More than 90% of eligible students picked up their free computers by the end of November 2006.

body_text.text: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

Following previous research, we use the course-taking behavior of students as a measure of the interest and likelihood of transferring to 4-year colleges (California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office 2009, Sengupta and Jepsen 2006).
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: From an analysis of a special cohort of entering students for the 1997-1998 school year linked through system-wide administrative data, Sengupta and Jepsen (2006) find that enrollment in transferable courses in the first and second years of study is a major predictor of who eventually transfers.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Butte College provided us with administrative data on all courses taken by study participants over a 2-year period starting at the beginning of the experiment.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: All of the courses taken by students can be identified as being transferable to the California State University (CSU) or University of California (UC) systems.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: For all courses offered at Butte College, 71% are transferable to CSU or UC campuses.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Transferable courses are spread across a large number of different departments with 86% of departments offering at least one transferable course.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: The number of transferable courses offered by the college and in each department is reported in Table A1.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Transferable courses can be higher level courses even though they satisfy lower division credit.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: In Mathematics, for example, Intermediate Algebra is not transferable and Analytic Geometry/Calculus I is transferable to CSU and UC campuses.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Of all courses taken by participants in the experiment 63% are transferable to CSU or UC systems.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: We also examine actual transfer rates of students participating in the study.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: For a special study of transfer rates to 4-year colleges, the Institutional Research Department at Butte College purchased data tracking college enrollment activity from the National Student Clearinghouse.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Data tracking college enrollment activity through summer 2010 were purchased for every student attending Butte College over the previous several years.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: We recently found out about the project, and the Institutional Research Department provided us with the data from this special run for all students participating in our random experiment.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: The system tracks attendance at most colleges in the United States and includes information from CSU and UC campuses.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: This source is essential because community colleges do not collect (and have no easy way of collecting) information themselves on which students leave and ultimately transfer to 4-year universities.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Using these data we find that 21.6% of study participants transfer to a 4-year college in the 4-year window.
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Most of the transferring students transfer to CSU campuses (89.9%).
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: Of these students transferring to CSU campuses, most transfer to California State University Chico (75.9%).
body_text.section: D. Data on Transfer Courses and Transfer Rates

body_text.text: No study participants transfer to University of California campuses.

body_text.text: III.
THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES
Before turning to the results from the experiment, we examine how the California Community College System provides a transfer function to 4-year universities.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Butte College is part of the California Community College system, which is the largest higher educational system in the nation.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: The system includes 112 colleges and educates 2.6 million students per year (California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office 2012).
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: As stated in the Master Plan for Higher Education in California, the primary mission of community colleges is to provide academic and vocational instruction through the first 2 years of undergraduate education (University of California Office of the President 2009).
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: The Plan specifically calls for community colleges to play an important role in admission to the state's 4-year universities.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Eligible students transferring from community colleges are given priority in the admissions process at CSU and UC campuses, and CSU and UC campuses are required to establish a specified lower division to upper division ratio to facilitate transfers.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Agreements between California community colleges and CSU or UC campuses often make it easier for students to transfer as long as they meet specific criteria about taking courses and obtaining grade thresholds.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: The most common 4-year college that Butte College students transfer to is CSU Chico, which is the closest CSU campus.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: The eligibility requirements for an upper division transfer to CSU Chico are that students have at least 60 semester (or 90 quarter) transferable units, with 30 semester units of general education (GE).
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: The student must receive a grade of C or higher in the GE courses, and have a 2.0 or higher overall grade point average (GPA).
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Transfers to CSU Chico from community colleges that are outside of their local admission area often face higher GPA requirements.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Community college students can also apply to a 4-year college at an earlier stage (referred to as a lower division transfer), but these students have a lower priority in admissions than the upper division transfer applicants.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Attending a community college before attending a 4-year university may be especially attractive to low-income students.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: The tuition savings from attending 2 years at a community college are substantial.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: From the perspective of the UC and CSU systems, a strikingly large percentage of students first attended a community college in California (California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office 2009).
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: In the CSU system, 55.3% of students from the 2007-2008 cohort previously attended a community college.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Of the 42,416 students in the 2007-2008 cohort in the University of California system, 29.4% previously attended a community college.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: The community college system clearly provides a route to university education for many students in California.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Identifying the potential barriers to transferring to 4-year colleges for other students is important for improving overall access to higher education.
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: Informational constraints may represent one such barrier to attending 4-year colleges, especially among low-income students (American Association of Community Colleges 2004; Dowd and Gabbard 2006;Furchtgott-Roth, Jacobson, and Mokher 2009).
body_text.section: III. THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY COLLEGE AS A GATEWAY TO 4-YEAR COLLEGES

body_text.text: IV.
HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS
The impact of home computers on students deciding to transfer is ambiguous.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: Home computers may provide an important tool for finding information about 4-year colleges and help students take challenging transferable courses and ultimately transfer to 4-year colleges.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: For example, students with home computers and access to the Internet would have more flexibility to explore websites such as "assist.org," which allows California community college students to enter their current college and 4-year college of interest and obtain detailed information on which courses are transferrable, different majors, general requirements to earn a degree in that major, and links to other college-related websites.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: However, computers also allow students to gather more information on the value and requirements of getting an associate's or vocational degree, which may discourage students from transferring to 4-year colleges, as well as provide a distraction through their entertainment value.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: In this section, we turn to the field experiment to estimate the transfer function of home computers.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: We first examine impacts on the likelihood that community college students take courses that are transferable to the CSU or UC systems before turning to an analysis of data on actual transfers.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: Enrollment in transfer courses proxies for potential interest in transferring which is an important outcome in addition to actual transfers.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: Among study participants, 63% of all courses taken over the study period are transferable.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: Of all courses taken by the treatment group, 66% are transferable to a CSU or UC campus compared with 61% of courses taken by the control group.
body_text.section: IV. HOME COMPUTER IMPACTS

body_text.text: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance
The estimates presented thus far capture the ITT from the experiment and do not adjust for noncompliance in the treatment and control groups.
body_text.section: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance

body_text.text: Some of the students in the treatment group did not pick up their free computers, and some of the students in the control group purchased their own computers during the study period.
body_text.section: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance

body_text.text: Although the ITT estimate is often a parameter of interest in evaluating policies to address the consequences of disparities in access to technology, the "treatment-on-the-treated" (TOT), or more general, local average treatment effect (LATE) estimates are also of interest.
body_text.section: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance

body_text.text: They provide estimates of the effects of having a home computer on the probability of taking transfer courses.
body_text.section: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance

body_text.text: Of the 141 students in the study that were eligible to receive a free computer, 129 students (or 92%) actually picked them up from Computers for Classrooms.
body_text.section: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance

body_text.text: To adjust for this noncompliance by the treatment group and obtain the TOT estimate, an instrumental variables (IV) regression is estimated.
body_text.section: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance

body_text.text: Computer eligibility (winning a free computer) is used as an instrumental variable for whether the student picked up the free computer.
body_text.section: A. Adjusting for Noncompliance

body_text.text: B. Impacts on Transfers to 4-Year Colleges
We now turn to estimating the effects of home computers on actual transfers to 4-year colleges.
body_text.section: B. Impacts on Transfers to 4-Year Colleges

body_text.text: Although home computers increase the likelihood of taking transferable courses they might have a different effect on actual transfers to 4year colleges in which students face additional constraints.
body_text.section: B. Impacts on Transfers to 4-Year Colleges

body_text.text: Constraints may include the high cost, reduced flexibility in course offerings to accommodate working, and more challenging coursework of 4-year universities (Council on Postsecondary Education 2004).
body_text.section: B. Impacts on Transfers to 4-Year Colleges

body_text.text: As noted above, information on transfers to 4-year colleges is obtained from college enrollment data from the beginning of the experiment through 4 years later.
body_text.section: B. Impacts on Transfers to 4-Year Colleges

body_text.text: We find that 21.3% of the treatment group transfers to a 4-year college compared with 20.0% of the control group.

body_text.text: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates
It is useful to consider how large of a sample size would be needed to estimate economically meaningful estimates for the actual transfer rate.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: Power calculations are relatively simple when comparing two proportions because the variance of the treatment and control means are determined by the base proportion along with the sample size (i.e., no assumptions about the variance of the two means are needed).
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: From the experiment, the control group mean for the actual transfer rate is 0.20, and the point estimates indicate treatment effect sizes of roughly 0.010-0.013.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: Table A2 reports power calculations assuming different effect sizes.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: The effect size would have to be 0.10 (or 50% of the control group mean) to be statistically detectable with sample sizes in the range of what is available in this experiment.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: How do we translate these hypothetical treatment effects sizes into whether they are economically meaningful, and thus whether we can detect economically meaningful treatment effects with different sample sizes?
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: One way is to place them in the perspective of reducing disparities in transfer rates.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: For example, the state-wide difference in transfer rates between underrepresented minorities and whites is roughly 10 percentage points (Sengupta and Jepsen 2006), suggesting that a policy intervention that could reduce this racial gap by one fifth (a 0.02 treatment effect) would be economically meaningful.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: Another method of assessing the magnitude is to examine the total cost of influencing one more student to transfer and comparing it to the potential returns to transferring.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: A treatment effect of 0.02 which is 10% of the control group mean implies that 50 computers (at a total cost of roughly $22,500) would have to be given out to increase the number of students transferring by 1.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: A total cost of $45,000 would be required to induce one more transfer with a treatment effect of 0.01 (5% of the control group mean).
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: U.S. Census Bureau (2011) estimates indicate that mean annual earnings for individuals with a bachelor's degree are nearly $25,000 higher than with an associate's degree.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: However, the actual average returns to transferring are likely to be much lower with the uncertainty of obtaining a degree.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: If these returns were only $5,000 per year then the total cost of the computers would be recovered in a few years if the treatment effect is 0.02, but would take much longer for an effect size of 0.01.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: Although it is difficult to determine what an economically meaningful effect size would be in this context, it appears as though an effect size of 0.02 is clearly large, economically meaningful, and policy relevant, but even in this case we would need 6,510 observations to obtain statistical significance.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: For convenience, Table A2 also presents information from power calculations in terms of the 20.

body_text.text: Nonproportion outcome measures that have high variances require especially large sample sizes to reach statistical significance (see Lewis and Reiley 2011, for an example).
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: confidence intervals generated by the sample size of the experiment (N = 286) and a much larger sample size (N = 5,000) for the same set of possible treatment effects.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: With the sample size used in the experiment the confidence intervals on all of the effect sizes are large, often around 10 percentage points or 50% of the control group mean on either side of the estimate.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: Even in the case of the larger sample size with 5,000 observations, which would represent a very expensive experiment, the sample size is not large enough to detect a 0.01 or 0.02 treatment effect.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: The confidence intervals, however, would be slightly more than 2 percentage points on either side of the estimate (or 10% of the control group mean).

body_text.text: These power calculations demonstrate how difficult it is to find a statistically significant treatment effect or obtain relatively tight confidence intervals for an expensive per-participant experiment.
body_text.section: C. Power Calculations for Actual Transfer Estimates

body_text.text: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal
The focus thus far has been on estimating the average treatment effect for all study participants.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: The literature on the transfer function of community colleges, however, has emphasized the importance of controlling for the educational goals of community college students (see Leigh andGill 2003, 2007;Alfonso 2006;and Long and Kurlaender 2009, for example).
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

ref_spans.text: and Long and Kurlaender 2009, for example)

body_text.text: Students attend community colleges for many different reasons potentially placing them at varying levels of risk of having a desire to take transfer courses and transfer to 4-year colleges.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: As reported in Table 3 and discussed above, we find from administrative data based on the self-reported educational goals of students on their original application to the college, 37.4% of study participants reported being "undecided," 31.5% reported "transfer to a 4-year institution," and 24.5% reported a goal other than transferring to a 4-year college.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Controlling for these educational goals has little effect on the treatment effect estimates, but there is the possibility that having a home computer may have differential effects on transfer behavior depending on the initial goals of the student.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Table 8 provides evidence on this question from regressions in which treatment status is interacted with the three major educational goals at the time of application.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: The main treatment effect captures the treatment effect for the most common educational goal, "undecided."
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: For taking transfer courses, we find that home computers have essentially no effect on "undecided" Notes: The dependent variable is whether the course is transferable to a California State University or University of California campus in Specifications 1 and 2 and whether the student transfers to a 4-year college in Specifications 3 and 4.

body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Baseline controls include gender, race/ethnicity, age, parents' highest education level, high school grades, presence of own children, live with parents, family income, and educational goals.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: students.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: The effects of home computers on taking transfer courses are stronger, however, for students with an initial goal of transferring to a 4-year college.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: We also find that students with nontransfer goals are relatively more likely to take transferable courses when receiving a free computer.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: The computer may have changed their goal or simply allowed these students to take more challenging and demanding courses at the community college.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: We also explore heterogeneity in treatment effects on transfers to 4-year colleges by initial educational goal.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Specification 3 of Table 8 reports these estimates.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: The results are less clear.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: We find a positive point estimate on the treatment interaction with having a transfer goal, but the coefficient is small and insignificant.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: We also find a large negative point estimate on the treatment interaction with having a nontransfer goal, but the coefficient is not significant at conventional levels (t-stat = 1.31).
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Although we should interpret this coefficient with some caution, it suggests the possibility that home computers facilitated these students in taking more advanced transfer courses, but did not ultimately increase their likelihood of transferring to a 4-year college.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Instead of using educational goals selfreported by students at the time of application as a measure of transfer goals, we can use pre-treatment transfer course-taking behavior in fall 2006.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: 21 Fall 2006 is generally the first year of courses taken for study participants, and course choices for this term were made prior to when the computers were distributed, which was in October and November 2006.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: We create a variable that measures the percentage of courses taken in fall 2006 that are transferable for each student.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: The average value for this variable is 60.5% for the control group and 61.4% for the treatment group.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: The difference of 0.9% is small and not statistically significant.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: We interact a dummy variable indicating whether the student had a fall 2006 transfer course percentage higher than the median (0.67) and treatment status, and include it in the regressions reported in Specifications 2 and 4 of Table 8.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: For the transfer course regression we find a positive main effect of computers, but find a small negative and insignificant coefficient on treatment interacted with taking a large percentage of transfer courses prior to treatment.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: In the actual transfer regression, we find a small negative coefficient on the main treatment effect and a large positive coefficient on the treatment effect interacted with taking a large percentage of transfer courses in fall 2006.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Although the interaction coefficients 21.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Sengupta and Jepsen (2006) argue that first-year course taking represents a more reliable measure of transfer goals than responses on the application form.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: are not precisely measured, they line up with the findings for treatment interactions with the educational goals students reported at the time of application to the college.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Overall, we find some suggestive evidence indicating that home computers might have helped community college students with the goal of transferring more in taking transfer courses and ultimately transferring to a 4-year college.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: 22 For community college students who did not have the goal of transferring, home computers may have encouraged them to take more challenging and demanding transfer courses, but had no differential effect on actual transfers.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: Unfortunately, we cannot draw strong conclusions from any of these results because of the general lack of precision of estimates.
body_text.section: D. Treatment Heterogeneity by Educational Goal

body_text.text: E. College Search
Students receiving free computers may have been more likely to search for information about colleges because of the increased time, flexibility, and autonomy of use offered by having a home computer.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: Finding more information about 4-year college choices, requirements, financial aid, and what courses are transferable may represent one of the main reasons computer recipients are more likely to take transferable courses.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: It also might explain why treatment students have a higher level of actual transfers (although we note again the lack of statistical significance).
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: On the follow-up survey, we asked students what they used computers for in the past month.
body_text.section: E. College Search
E. College Search

body_text.text: We also examine treatment heterogeneity by race and gender.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: Jepsen (2008) finds differences in 2-and 4-year college completion rates by race and gender.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: We find no evidence of different effects by race or gender.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: 23. We conducted a follow-up survey of study participants (treatment and control) in late spring/summer 2008 with particular, we asked them whether they searched for information about college choices.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: We found that the treatment group was nearly 10 percentage points more likely to report searching for college information than the control group in spring/summer 2008.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: Among the treatment group, 43.3% of students reported searching for college information in the past month compared with 34.1% of the control group.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The difference, however, is not statistically significant at conventional levels.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: From a regression analysis reported in Table 9, we find that the treatment effect estimate is not sensitive to the inclusion of controls.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: We find that the treatment group has a 10.9 percentage point higher likelihood of searching for college information than the control group.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: Although the difference is not significant at conventional levels for a two-tailed test (the p value is .126 for a two-tailed test), the point estimate suggests a potentially large effect.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The point estimates imply an effect of 9.2-10.9 percentage points.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: These point estimates imply large effects relative to the average probability of searching for college information among the control group of 34.1%, but the confidence intervals are also large.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The confidence interval for the treatment effect estimates including controls is [−0.030 to 0.248].
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: Power calculations indicate that slightly larger sample sizes would be needed to detect a statistically significant treatment effect given the control group mean of 0.34 and an effect size of 10 percentage points.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The detection of smaller treatment a response rate of 65%.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The baseline characteristics of the respondent sample look roughly similar to those of the full sample (see Fairlie and London 2012).
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The response rate was 61% for the control group and 69% for the treatment group.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The difference is not statistically significant.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: effects, however, would require much larger sample sizes.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: These findings are consistent with previous qualitative research indicating the importance of computers and the Internet for acquiring college information (Jones 2009;Owens 2007;Venegas 2007).
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: Venegas (2007) finds that the Internet is used extensively by students in the search and application process for college and financial aid.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: She finds that low-income students in her study were at a major disadvantage in applying to colleges and for financial aid because of their lack of access to computers at school and home.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: In her study of African American students, Jones (2009) finds that middle-class families have better access to computers at home than working-class families, and take advantage of this access to search more for college information.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: There is also direct evidence on the extensive use of technology among community college students, especially with colleges' online systems, to help in the transfer process to 4-year colleges (Owens 2007).
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: In contrast, there is some evidence of the varying, "haphazard," or "accidental" quality of transfer counseling at community colleges (Dowd and Gabbard 2006), and criticism of transfer advising because of the use of part-time faculty and large caseloads (Council on Postsecondary Education 2004).
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: The increased flexibility, time, and autonomy offered by having access to a home computer may enable low-income community college students to expand their ability to search for information about 4-year colleges.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: 24 Although home computers also improve the ability to search for information about 2-year degrees and certificates, the relative effect may be much lower because these students are already enrolled in a community college where nonelectronic information is readily available on campus.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: Improving college search might be an important mechanism for the causal relationship between home computers and taking transferable courses, although there is also the possibility that it reflects another measure of desire to transfer.
body_text.section: E. College Search

body_text.text: V. CONCLUSIONS
Rapidly rising tuition costs and recent calls to expand 2-year college enrollments suggest that community colleges will provide an increasingly 24.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Having access to a home computer may be especially useful for finding financial aid and scholarship information (Grazzi andVergara 2009a, 2009b).
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: important transfer function to 4-year colleges.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Community colleges in some states, such as California, already play a major role in university education with nearly half of all 4-year college students having previously attended a community college (California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office 2009).
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: In this paper, we use data from the first-ever randomized field experiment providing free computers to students for home use to explore whether having access to home computers improves the transfer function of community colleges.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: If limited information is an important constraint for transferring to 4-year colleges, especially among low-income community college students, then having access to computers at home may help overcome this barrier and lead to higher labor market returns.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The results from the field experiment indicate that the treatment group of students receiving free computers to use at home has a 4.8 percentage point higher probability of taking transferable courses than the control group of students not receiving free computers.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Of courses taken by the treatment group, 66% are transferable to CSU or UC campuses compared with 61% of courses taken by the control group.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Controlling for baseline characteristics does not change the conclusion-the treatment group of students receiving free computers has a 4.5 percentage point higher likelihood of taking transferable courses.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: LATE estimates of the effects of having a home computer on taking transferable courses range from 4.9 to 6.3 percentage points.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The results are less clear for the effects of home computers on actual transfers to 4-year colleges.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: We find positive point estimates for the treatment effect on actual transfers, but the estimates are not statistically significant.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The confidence intervals for these estimates are wide and only rule out very large negative and large positive effects.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Power calculations also reveal that large, prohibitively expensive sample sizes would be needed to obtain statistical significance unless the point estimates were larger.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Although the sample sizes would have to be considerably larger to reach statistical significance, the point estimates provide some suggestive evidence that the effects of home computers might be smaller on actual transfer rates than the effects on taking transferable courses.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Home computers may have changed the desire to transfer or increased student confidence in taking more challenging and demanding transfer courses, but other barriers to transferring to 4-year colleges were just too large.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Barriers such as the cost of 4-year colleges, added challenge of taking 4-year college courses, and lack of courses offered to accommodate nontraditional or working students might be especially restrictive (Council on Postsecondary Education 2004).
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: We find some evidence that students who did not initially have a goal of transferring to a 4-year college had larger positive effects from the computers than undecided and transfer goal students.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: We also find some suggestive evidence that students with transfer goals benefit more from home computers in terms of increasing their likelihood of transferring to 4-year colleges.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: We also find suggestive evidence that college search increases from receiving home computers.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Point estimates indicate that the treatment group has a roughly 10 percentage point higher probability of using a computer to search for college information than the control group (although again confidence intervals are large).
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The expanded ability of low-income community college students to find information about 4-year colleges may represent one of the mechanisms by which home computers increase transferable course taking.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Although there is concern that information constraints may limit interest in and the likelihood of transferring to 4-year colleges among low-income community college students, there is little direct evidence on the question.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The findings from this experiment suggest that having access to a home computer may be useful for finding information about 4-year university choices, admission requirements, tuition, financial aid, and which courses are transferable, which ultimately may counteract some of the "diversion" effects of attending a community college.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The 1.2 million community college students in the United States without access to home computers and the Internet, however, may be at a disadvantage in acquiring information helpful for transferring to 4-year universities and obtaining jobs requiring these skills.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: To overcome this barrier, policies that provide access to computers for low-income students, such as tax breaks or special loans for educational computer purchases, expanded computer refurbishing programs, and laptop checkout programs may be needed (Servon 2002, Warschauer 2006.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Addressing this barrier may become increasingly important as more application, financial aid, registration and course information is being placed online and public institutions reduce staff in response to budget cutbacks.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: More research on these important questions, preferably with larger sample sizes, is clearly needed.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Notes: All power calculations are for proportion outcomes and assumed 0.05 level of significance, 0.8 power, and no continuity correction.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: In STATA used sampsi and SAS used proc power.
body_text.section: V. CONCLUSIONS
